Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Liquid Chromatograph-Tandem Quadrupole-Orbitrap Fourier Transform Mass Spectrometer for High-Throughput Biological Analyses
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the University of Tennessee (UT) to acquire a Dionex UltiMate 3000 liquid chromatograph-Q Exactive Plus tandem quadrupole-Orbitrap Fourier transform mass spectrometer (LC Q Exactive), which will be the center piece instrument of the institution's Biological and Small Molecule Mass Spectrometry Core (BSMMSC) that provides state-of-the-art metabolomics and lipidomics support. This instrument will have broad impacts for the training and outreach capabilities or the institution and core, and acquisition of the LC-Q Exactive will strengthen both intra- and inter-organizational collaborations by providing new capabilities and infrastructure. Further, this instrument will also have impacts for UT's teaching mission as it will be used to train a diverse pool of post-doctoral, graduate, and undergraduate researchers. At the undergraduate level, introduction to meritorious research in the emerging fields of metabolomics and biological mass spectrometry will not only be accomplished through independent research courses but also through summer undergraduate programs and classroom exercises. The instrument will be made available to enhance two NSF Research Experience for Undergraduate (REU) programs in the departments of Microbiology and Chemistry at UT Knoxville; and the PI and Co- PIs are also working to develop a new co-listed Nutrition and Chemistry course that will utilize the LC-Q Exactive. At the graduate level, the instrument will be made available for research, and users will receive training on all aspects of experimental design and execution. Further, the LC-Q Exactive will be made available to graduate courses given by the Chemistry, Nutrition, and Biochemistry and Cellular and Molecular Biology departments to enhance instruction in these classes. The PI and Co-PIs will make these resources available to help broaden participation in the STEM disciplines and will collaborate with Mr. Travis Griffin and the NSF Funded Tennessee Louis Stokes Association for Minority Participation (TLSAMP) program to identify undergraduate student participants from underrepresented groups and with Dr. Laurie Richardson at Florida International University (~75% of students from this institution are from underrepresented groups.) to engage both undergraduate and graduate students.

Systems Biology technologies are important drivers for biological investigation and discovery,and these tools fall into three broad categories: genomics, proteomics, and metabolomics. The systems biology hierarchy aims to measure genes and RNA transcripts, protein content, and metabolic activity, respectively. While genomics and proteomics platforms are well established, metabolomics and (and to some extent lipidomics) platform development is still in its infancy. Significant infrastructure for systems biology is needed at UT to ensure that approaches which integrate large scale measures of transcripts, proteins and metabolites to develop holistic models of cellular, tissue and organismal function are available to the University community and others in the region. The LC-Q Exactive system will allow the development of novel techniques for discovery metabolomics and lipidomics and will provide the BSMMSC with basic targeted proteomics capabilities that will bolster available resources for bioanalytical science and advance capabilities in the region. A number of researchers within or near the UT Knoxville campus will benefit from these capabilities to measure metabolites, lipids, and proteins that can be applied to the study of all kingdoms of life. This instrument will enable research in a broad range of scientific fields ranging including, but not limited to, marine environmental science, soil microbiology, eukaryotic and prokaryotic biochemistry, computer science, and analytical chemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:

Systems Biology technologies are important drivers for biological investigation and discovery, and these tools fall into three broad categories: genomics, proteomics, and metabolomics/lipidomics. The systems biology hierarchy aims to measure genes and RNA messages, protein content, and metabolic activity, respectively. While genomics and proteomics platforms are well established, metabolomics and (and to some extent lipidomics) platform development is still developing. Significant infrastructure for systems biology is needed at the University of Tennessee (UT) to ensure that approaches which integrate large scale measures of transcripts, proteins and metabolites to develop holistic models of cellular, tissue and organismal function are available to the University and other researchers in the region. The Biological and Small Molecule Mass Spectrometry Center (BSMMSC) at UT Knoxville addresses this need by providing state-of-the-art metabolomics and lipidomics support as well as limited proteomics support. This award provided a liquid chromatograph–tandem quadrupole-Orbitrap Fourier transform mass spectrometer (LC-Q Exactive) that is the center piece instrument of the BSMMSC. The Dionex UltiMate 3000-based LC for this MS incorporates both a normal flow ultra-performance liquid chromatographic (UPLC) pump for standard metabolomics and lipidomics analyses as well as a nano high performance liquid chromatographic (nano-HPLC) pump for handling samples of smaller size. The UPLC-Q Exactive has provided much needed molecular discovery capabilities for water soluble metabolites and lipids and has facilitated targeted proteomics capacity that was not previously available on the UT campus.

 

Intellectual Merit:

The LC-Q Exactive system has allowed the development of novel techniques for discovery metabolomics and lipidomics and provided the BSMMSC with basic targeted proteomics capabilities that have bolstered available resources for bioanalytical science and advance capabilities in the region and beyond. The core has served nearly 60 laboratories from 13 different countries over the last three years, and it currently analyzes approximately 20,000 samples per year on a fee-for-service basis with the aid of two full time staff members. The specialized analyses performed on the UPLC-Q Exactive comprise approximately 16% of the total volume of the core and have expanded the types and quality of data that are provided to BSMMSC users. This instrument has enabled research in a broad range of scientific fields ranging including, but no limited to, marine environmental science, soil microbiology, eukaryotic and prokaryotic biochemistry, computer science, and analytical chemistry; and the UPLC-Q Exactive has provided data in support of nearly $2.5M in NSF funded projects at UT Knoxville alone in the last three years. Existing experience in the BSMMSC coupled with new instrumental capabilities allowed us to provide support for ongoing research activities within months of initial instrument installation, and we have continued to utilize the resources provided by this award to contribute to the endeavors of the UT and broader community of biological scientists and engineers by developing new metabolomics, lipidomics, and targeted proteomics methods to meet specific research needs..

 

Broader Impacts:

Acquisition of the LC-Q Exactive has strengthened both intra- and inter-organizational collaborations by providing new capabilities and infrastructure. This instrument has also impacted UT’s teaching mission as it has been used to train a diverse pool of post-doctoral, graduate, and undergraduate researchers. At the undergraduate level, introduction to meritorious research in the emerging fields of metabolomics and biological mass spectrometry was accomplished through independent research courses and also through summer undergraduate programs and classroom exercises in our newly established chemical biological classroom laboratory. The instrument was also made available to enhance two NSF Research Experience for Undergraduate (REU) programs in the departments of Microbiology and Chemistry at UT Knoxville. At the graduate level, the instrument was made available for research, and over 40 student users received training on all aspects of experimental design and execution. Further, the LC-Q Exactive was used in a graduate level biological mass spectrometry course that draws students from numerous entities including: microbiology, biological and cellular and molecular biology, ecology and evolutionary biology, the UT Institute or Agriculture, and the genome science and technology program. The PI and Co-PIs have also made these resources available to help broaden participation in the STEM disciplines and collaborated with Mr. Travis Griffin and the NSF Funded Tennessee Louis Stokes Association for Minority Participation (TLSAMP) program to identify undergraduate student participants from underrepresented groups to work with the BSMMSC.
